title: How to get publication as an undergraduate medical student - Quora

response.answer_text: I'm wondering whether your misspeaking or from a different country, because there are no undergraduate medical students in the United States. Medical school is a graduate school; you enter it after having completed a bachelors degree, which usually takes four years. Dr. Christopher Fox gave a fine answer for an undergraduate premed biology or chemistry major who is able to work on a solid project at the University. My understanding is that during your first year of medical school, you won't be able to do any serious amount of independent work; the people who seem to succeed spend their time studying, sleeping, and not much else.

Getting involved with research with one of your professor is the best way, possibly leading to a good quality publication. However, that requires a lot of time and patience because the publication may only come years after the project. I often advise my student who know what specialty the want to get into to find a mentor in that field and work on a case report with them. Many practising physicians have a case or two that they want to publish as a case report but don’t have time. It’s a good and relatively easy opportunity to get published.
